Build 2004-05-12... but I checked the most recent code and I think it's still a 
problem.

I can't seem to use a variable (created using a user Parameter) in the Thread 
Group's Number of Threads field.  Maybe this was done by design but it was not 
mentioned in the User's manual (I check chapter 3 (or 4; whereever Thread Group 
is described) as well as the reference chapter).

When I use a variable the logs state that 0 threads are being started and 
JMeter hangs.

See the attached test case for an example...  You can replace the variable with 
a number and watch the test run fine.

sebb@apache.org
text:
User Parameters is a pre-processor, so is only invoked just before a sampler, 
by which time it is too late to affect the Thread Group.

Try putting the variables in the Test Plan instead, or pass them in using a 
property - see the JMeter FAQ for some examples.

The User Parameters variables *are* picked up by the sampler.

It is a separate (minor) bug that JMeter misbehaves when the loop count is 
zero.

I don't quite understand this behaviour; I use a user-parameter to control the 
Loop Count which is in the thread group node so why can't a user-parameters 
control the thread count which is in the same node?

Also, note, you mentioned below: "It is a separate (minor) bug that JMeter 
misbehaves when the loop count is zero."  It's actually the Thread Number, not 
the Loop Count that went to zero when the parameter was passed in; I just don't 
want someone looking in the wrong place.
creator: martin123456789@hotmail.com

text:
I've just tried again, and I agree that the Number of Threads field does not
pick up the value of the variable. The Ramp up field behaves similarly.

Both of these fields are used _before_ the test threads have been started,
whereas the loop count is handled by each thread individually, and this occurs
_after_ the variables have been set up.

I think it's behaving as designed, even if at first it appears counter-intuitive.

However it is a bug that JMeter does not behave well when the _thread_ count is
set to zero, and, as already mentioned, when the _loop_ count is zero.

OK?
